content.question: The simplest amino acid is glycine. When glycine dissolves in water, it forms a zwitterion, which is a neutral molecule that has separated positive and negative formal charges. The Lewis diagram for the zwitterion form of glycine is shown in the box. A. Draw a positive sign (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) and a negative sign (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) on the diagram to identify the atoms in the zwitterion that bear a positive and negative formal charge, respectively.

frqParts.text: The simplest amino acid is glycine. When glycine dissolves in water, it forms a zwitterion, which is a neutral molecule that has separated positive and negative formal charges. The Lewis diagram for the zwitterion form of glycine is shown in the box. A. Draw a positive sign (<math alttext="plus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) and a negative sign (<math alttext="minus" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>) on the diagram to identify the atoms in the zwitterion that bear a positive and negative formal charge, respectively.

Glycine, which can form hydrogen bonds with <math alttext="H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> molecules, is soluble in water. B. Draw water molecules ( ) in the diagram to show the formation of hydrogen bonds with the glycine zwitterion. Draw at least one water molecule in the correct orientation near each charge in the zwitterion.

C. What mass of glycine (molar mass <math alttext="75.07 grams per mole" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>75.07</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>g/mol</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> ) should be weighed out to prepare <math alttext="250.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of a <math alttext="1.600 molar" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>1.600</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> solution of glycine in water? Report your answer using the correct number of significant figures.

D. A student places solid glycine in a clean, empty <math alttext="250 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>250</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> volumetric flask, adds enough distilled water to dissolve the glycine, then carefully fills the flask to the correct total volume. In the magnified side view in the following diagram, sketch the shape and position of the meniscus of the solution relative to the calibration line etched on the neck of the flask, indicating a properly filled flask.

E. The student notices that when the solid readily dissolved, the flask became cool to the touch. What can the student conclude from these observations about the signs of <math alttext="delta H naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, and <math alttext="delta S naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for the dissolution reaction? Justify your answers in terms of thermochemistry and thermodynamic favorability.

The student prepares to titrate the glycine solution using the titration reaction represented by the following balanced net-ionic equation. <math alttext="N H 3 C H 2 C O 2, plus O H with a negative 1 charge, react to produce N H 2 C H 2 C O 2 with a negative 1 charge, plus H 2 O" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mtext>OH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>→</mo><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>CH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msup><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>CO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow><mrow><mo>−</mo></mrow></msup><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext></mrow></math> A <math alttext="10.00 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>10.00</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sample of the glycine solution is added to a clean, empty <math alttext="125 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>125</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Erlenmeyer flask, which is then placed under a clean, empty <math alttext="50 milliliter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> buret. The available laboratory reagents are listed in the following table. Distilled water <math alttext="0.500 molar H C l" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HCl</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> <math alttext="0.500 molar N a O H" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.500</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NaOH</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Methyl orange indicator <math alttext="p K sub a, equals 3.4" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mtext>p</mtext> <msub> <mrow> <mi>K</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>3.4</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> Phenolphthalein indicator <math alttext="p K sub a, equals 9.4" overflow="scroll"> <mstyle> <mrow> <mo>(</mo> <mtext>p</mtext> <msub> <mrow> <mi>K</mi> </mrow> <mrow> <mi>a</mi> </mrow> </msub> <mo>=</mo> <mn>9.4</mn> <mo>)</mo> </mrow> </mstyle> </math> F. For the titration procedure, identify the following from the table. i. The reagent(s) that should be used to fill the buret ii. The reagent(s) that should be added to the glycine solution in the Erlenmeyer flask

skill.text: 2.C: Identify experimental procedures that are aligned to a scientific question (which may include a sketch of a lab setup).
